Award.AwardTitle: IEEE PerCom 2017 Student Travel Support Request

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to provide travel support for the IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications to be held in Kona, Big Island, Hawaii on March 13-17, 2017. The conference includes papers on many technologies that are fundamental to Cyber-Physical Systems specifically, including sensor systems and Internet of Things, as well as the computer and information sciences more broadly. This project will fund 20-25 students to attend the conference, and a selection committee and a selection process will be used to choose from potential invitees.

The conference will organize a PhD Forum for students and will provide important networking opportunities for the students. The attendance and participation in conference activities including the PhD Forum and student sessions will have a strong impact on the education of the next generation of pervasive computing and cyber-physical system experts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom) is a flagship conference in the area of pervasive computing and networking. The NSF funds helped support 24 US students to attend IEEE PerCom 2017 conference held in Kona, Big Island, Hawaii on March 13-17, 2017 (www.percom.org). Seven of these selected students were women, four under-represented minority, and one military veteran. They consisted of one first-year postdoc, three undergraduate and five MS students, and the remaining were PhD students ranging from small schools to big name schools.

 

Intellectual Merit: Papers presented at the IEEE PerCom 2017 conference were very high quality. The technical topics included a wide variety of topic in pervasive computing and networking as well as emerging topics like smartphone sensing, crowdsourcing and crowd sensing, and social networks with applications to cyber-physical-human systems, smart and connected communities, smart healthcare, internet of things (IoT), security, energy and sustainability. The conference offered a valuable opportunity for the supported US-based students to attend keynote talks and technical sessions, learn about state-of-the-art research in pervasive computing, systems and applications through paper presentations and panel discussions, and participate in the through PhD forum, workshops, demo, poster, and work-in-progress sessions. The students also got the opportuinity to network wih peers. They were highly motivated to do high quality research and pursue research careers upon graduation.

 

Broader Impacts. The NSF travel support allowed 24 students including women and under-represented minority students to attend IEEE Percom 2017, a flagship conference in the field of pervasive computing. The NSF travel grant opportunity was widely advertised that led to the selection of students competitively from an application pool of more than 40 students. Without NSF travel support, many of these students would not otherwise have attended this top conference in the field.
